appearances.snippet: senator jeanne shaheen, we do appreciate your time on this remarkable day. thank you. let's go now to kevin liptak. we do have our panel with us as well. of course, john miller and jim sciutto, who who will be talking in just a bit. but let's first go to kevin. look, we are waiting to hear more. everyone wants to know more about what the plan is. although he did, the president lay out some of the plans, saying the united states will now run venezuela for a time. give us some sense of what you're hearing. if you're getting any updates on this as you cover the administration during this time. >> no. and, you know, the president was remarkably vague about what exactly he meant when he said that the u.s. was going to run venezuela going forward. you know, we heard so much from the briefers today about what went into this operation, the months and months of planning that was put in, the cia operatives who were tracking maduro on the ground. but when it came to what's going to happen today and tomorrow and then the next week and in the next month, the president really did no

appearances.snippet: joining us right now is democratic senator jeanne shaheen. she's the top democrat on the senate foreign relations committee was in that classified briefing amongst some amongst leaders yesterday. senator, thank you for being here. how would you characterize that briefing and the level of detail you received? >> well, we got significant detail with respect to the military mission, and there's no doubt that was masterful, both on the part of the men and women in our military who participated and the intel community that was critical to that. but in terms of what comes next and the actions that are going to secure the goals that the administration seems to be articulating for venezuela, there were there were not a lot of details. there were there were not the kind of benchmarks that we would hope to see for what what we want to see the regime do. and in fact, as has been pointed out, this was not regime change in venezuela. what we did was exchange one authoritarian leader in nicolas maduro for an authoritarian leader who has now been sworn in i

appearances.title: Squawk Box : CNBC : January 15, 2026 6:00am-9:00am EST
appearances.snippet: joining us now, one of the authors coauthors of the bill, senator jeanne shaheen.ator, thanks for joining us this morning. it's almost friday. almost. >> it is. >> yeah, it's almost friday. i'd like to say spr. can you think of it that way? can you explain exactly what you're proposing here? >> well, first of all, as you pointed out in the introduction, the united states has been at the whim of particularly china, our biggest adversary in terms of having access to those critical minerals that are so much a part of everything we need in our economy, whether it's missiles or refrigerators, cars, almost everything is dependent on some of those critical minerals. and this is an effort to try and reduce u.s. dependance on other countries. we saw during covid what happens when we are so dependent on other countries, when we had to borrow from china from other places to get the cover ups that we needed to address covid, and we don't want that to happen again. we saw this as an issue last year when the president tried to impose tariffs on china, and china came back and sai

appearances.title: Washington Journal 01/07/2026 : CSPAN : January 7, 2026 6:59am-10:01am EST
appearances.snippet: there was a rare bipartisan statement that came out last night from senator jeanne shaheen and senatortillis, democrat and republican, who sit on a subcommittee that oversees the u.s. relationship with denmark and other nato allies. this statement, this rare bipartisan statement said the president in the u.s. needs to learn to denmark when they say greenland is not for sale, it is nonnegotiable, and that they need to protect the integrity and the sovereignty of a u.s. ally like denmark. so obviously, some concerns. it is sort of surprising already to see some republican members of congress sort of publicly break with the administration on that. host: stephen neukam of axios, thank you for your time this morning. guest: thank you. host: we will turn back to open for them briefly. dennis from stone method, jointer, democrat, you are next. caller: good morning, c-span. my question to the american people is would it be ok for another country's president to come to the united states and do the same thing to this current president for exporting guns that are killing people all over the world
